content:
DelayActivity Class

Definition

Provides the logic to establish a timer and to wait, asynchronously, for timer's expiration. This class cannot be inherited.

In this Article

[System.ComponentModel.DefaultEvent("InitializeTimeoutDuration")]
[System.ComponentModel.Designer(typeof(System.Workflow.Activities.DelayDesigner), typeof(System.ComponentModel.Design.IDesigner))]
[System.ComponentModel.ToolboxItem(typeof(System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Design.ActivityToolboxItem))]
[System.Drawing.ToolboxBitmap(typeof(System.Workflow.Activities.DelayActivity), "Resources.Delay.png")]
[System.Obsolete("The System.Workflow.* types are deprecated.  Instead, please use the new types from System.Activities.*")]
[System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Compiler.ActivityValidator(typeof(System.Workflow.Activities.DelayActivity/DelayActivityValidator))]
public sealed class DelayActivity : System.Workflow.ComponentModel.Activity, System.Workflow.Activities.IEventActivity, System.Workflow.ComponentModel.IActivityEventListener<System.Workflow.ComponentModel.QueueEventArgs>

Remarks

Note

This material discusses types and namespaces that are obsolete. For more information, see Deprecated Types in Windows Workflow Foundation 4.5.

When notified that its timer has expired, a DelayActivity completes its execution.

You can set a time out on the DelayActivity so that your workflow pauses before resuming execution. You specify the TimeoutDuration using TimeSpan. This causes your workflow to pause until the specified TimeSpan has elapsed.

The DelayActivity class runs the code method associated with the InitializeTimeoutDuration event before the activity starts and the code-beside method can be used to initialize the TimeoutDuration property.

The DelayActivity is guaranteed to complete no sooner than the indicated TimeoutDuration. The delay can take longer because the timer notification might occur some time after the TimeoutDuration is reached. One reason for a longer delay is if the workflow is running under high system stress in a server environment.

Initializes a new instance of the DelayActivity class.

public DelayActivity ();

The user-defined name of the activity.

Fields

Represents the DependencyProperty that targets the InitializeTimeoutDuration event.

public static readonly System.Workflow.ComponentModel.DependencyProperty InitializeTimeoutDurationEvent;

Remarks

You indirectly access each public property and event of this type by the resolution of a corresponding dependency property. This dependency property is the public static field named XProperty or XEvent, where X is the corresponding property.

TimeoutDurationProperty

Represents the DependencyProperty that targets the stem.Workflow.Activities.DelayActivity.TimeoutDuration* property.

public static readonly System.Workflow.ComponentModel.DependencyProperty TimeoutDurationProperty;

Remarks

You indirectly access each public property and event of this type by the resolution of a corresponding dependency property. This dependency property is the public static field named XProperty or XEvent, where X is the corresponding property.

Properties

TimeoutDuration

Gets and sets the duration of the delay in the workflow.

public TimeSpan TimeoutDuration { get; set; }
Value
TimeSpan

A TimeSpan that indicates the length of the delay in the workflow.

Remarks

The time period set in this property determines the time the workflow will sit idle before the workflow proceeds to the next activity.

Events

InitializeTimeoutDuration

Occurs before the time-out duration starts.

public event EventHandler InitializeTimeoutDuration;

Remarks

This event should not be used to set the TimeoutDuration for a DelayActivity. The time-out duration should be set in the workflow's InitializeComponent method instead.

Explicit Interface Implementations

Gets the name of the workflow queue that will be delivered when the timer expires.

Remarks

The name of the workflow queue is set by the CreateWorkflowQueue method.
